chapter.title: Force Models
chapter.para: This tutorial was started from the default settings in the June 9, 2008 build of GMAT.

section.title: Objective and Overview
section.para: This tutorial demonstrates how to set up different force models and then propagate a spacecraft using those models. Modifying the types of force models affecting a spacecraft at certain points in a mission can be advantageous, for example, in simplifying a mission sequence, increasing accuracy, or reducing computing time.
You can download the script file and run it beforehand to see the final results of this tutorial: ForceModelsTutorial.script

listitem.para: Basic Understanding of how to create and propagate a spacecraft, as in Tutorial Creating and Propagating a Spacecraft
Objective: Propagate a spacecraft using several different force models. Compare the results from different models and differences in computing times.
Assume:
A given spacecraft in low earth orbit (LEO) with
A UTCGregorian Epoch of 04 Jan 2003 00:00:00.000
An Eccentricity of 0.2032349944098091
Find: (Observation only)

section.title: Creating and Configuring the Resource Tree
section.para: This mission requires only a simple resource tree. There is a single spacecraft, one OpenGL Plot, one report, and a series of 6 propagators to accomplish this mission. Everything else should be default. The steps on how to setup the resource tree is presented below.

listitem.para: Spacecraft: Sat1
Propagators: RKV89PointMass, RKV89ThirdBodies, RKV8912x12, RKV89MSISE90, RKV89JR, RKV89SRP
Plots/Reports: OpenGLSat1, ForceModelRpt
Spacecraft (Note: Figure below shows how the resulting Sat1 properties window should look like. Similar for other steps)
Rename DefaultSC to Sat1
Change the Epoch Format to UTCGregorian
Set the Epoch to 04 Jan 2003 00:00:00.000
Change the State Type to Keplerian
Set the Eccentricity to 0.2032349944098091
Set the remaining orbital elements to zero
Propagators
RKV89PointMass

This propagator simply sets the Earth as a point mass and uses it as the Force Model. All other propagators below, except for one (RKV8912x12), use Earth as a point mass as well. Figure below shows this propagator properties' window; windows for other propagators will look similarly.
Rename DefaultProp to RKV89PointMass
Set the Initial Step Size to 30
Set the Accuracy at 1e-012
Set the Min Step Size to 30
Set the Max Step Size to 30
Set the Degree in the Gravity Group box to 0
Set the Order in the Gravity Group box to 0
RKV89ThirdBodies
This propagator adds all the planets except Mercury and Pluto as point masses to the Force Model.
Add a Propagator and rename it RKV89ThirdBodies
Set the Initial Step Size to 30
Set the Accuracy at 1e-012
Set the Min Step Size to 30
Set the Max Step Size to 30 as well
Set the Degree in the Gravity Group box to 0
Set the Order in the Gravity Group box to 0
Add Sun, Luna, and all the planets except Mercury and Pluto to the Point Masses field
RKV8912x12
Unlike other propagators, this one does not set Earth as a point mass in the Force Model; it uses instead a 12x12 JGM-2 Gravity Model.
Add a Propagator and rename it RKV8912x12
Set the Initial Step Size to 30
Set the Accuracy at 1e-012
Set the Min Step Size to 30
Set the Max Step Size to 30 as well
Raise the Degree in the Gravity Group box to 12
Raise the Order in the Gravity Group box to 12
RKV89MSISE90
The Force Model in this Propagator calculates drag on the spacecraft based on the MSISE90 Atmospheric Model.
Add a Propagator and rename it RKV89MSISE90
Set the Accuracy at 1e-012
Set the Min Step Size to 30
Set the Max Step Size to 30 as well
Lower the Degree in the Gravity Group box to 0
Lower the Order in the Gravity Group box down to 0
Set the Atmosphere Model under the Drag Group Box to MSISE90
RKV89JR
The Force Model in this Propagator calculates drag on the spacecraft based on the Jacchia-Roberts Atmosphere Model.
Add a Propagator and rename it RKV89JR
Set the Initial Step Size to 30
Set the Accuracy at 1e-012
Set the Min Step Size to 30
Set the Max Step Size to 30 as well
Lower the Degree in the Gravity Group box to 0
Lower the Order in the Gravity Group box down to 0
Set the Atmosphere Model under the Drag Group Box to JacchiaRoberts
RKV89SRP
This propagator is like the first one (RKV89PointMass), with the only difference that it accounts for the Solar Radiation Pressure.
Add a Propagator and rename it RKV89SRP
Set the Initial Step Size to 30
Set the Accuracy at 1e-012
Set the Min Step Size to 30
Set the Max Step Size to 30 as well
Lower the Degree in the Gravity Group box to 0
Lower the Order in the Gravity Group box down to 0
Check the Use Solar Radiation Pressure Check box
Burns
Delete DefaultIB in the Resource tree
Plots/Reports
OpenGLSat1 OpenGL Plot
Rename DefaultOpenGL to OpenGLSat1
Set the Axis under the View Up Definition Group box to X
ForceModelRpt Report
Create a Report Named ForceModelRpt
Remove all Parameters from the Parameter List
Select the File as being ./output/SampleMissions/Ex_ForceModels.report

section.title: Creating and Configuring the Mission Sequence
section.para: In addition to the default layout, this mission sequence includes an initial Report and Equation, followed by a series of alternating Propagates and Reports. Consequently, the mission runs several different Propagators, with their progress reported back to the user via the generated report file.

listitem.para: Delete the initial Propagate
Append the Mission Sequence Folder with a Report: Add Sat1.X, Y, Z, VX, VY, and VZ to the Parameter List
Insert an Equation after Report 1. Set it to ForceModelRpt.WriteHeaders = Off
Insert a Propagate after Equation1
Set the Parameter Field to Sat1.ElapsedDays
Set the Condition Field to 0.1
Insert a Report after Propagate 1. Set it exactly as Report1
Insert a Propagate after Report2
Set the Propagator Field to RKV89ThirdBodies
Set the Stopping Conditions Group Box to match Propagate1
Insert a Report after Propagate 2. Set it exactly as Report1
Insert a Propagate after Report3
Set the Propagator Field to RKV8912x12
Set the Stopping Conditions Group Box to match Propagate1
Insert a Report after Propagate 3. Set it exactly as Report1
Insert a Propagate after Report4
Set the Propagator Field to RKV89MSISE90
Set the Stopping Conditions Group Box to match Propagate1
Insert a Report after Propagate 4. Set it exactly as Report1
Insert a Propagate after Report5
Set the Propagator Field to RKV89JR
Set the Stopping Conditions Group Box to match Propagate1
Insert a Report after Propagate 5. Set it exactly as Report1
Insert a Propagate after Report6
Set the Propagator Field to RKV89SRP
Set the Stopping Conditions Group Box to match Propagate1
Insert a Report after Propagate 6: Set it exactly as Report1

section.title: The resulting view of Resource, Mission, and Output trees

info.title: Figure: Force Models' Resource, Mission, and Output trees

caption.para: Figure: Force Models' Resource, Mission, and Output trees

section.title: Running the Mission
section.para: When running the mission, you will see the spacecraft Sat1 orbit the earth. Every one tenth of a day there is a switch to the Propagator that governs the Sat1 dynamics at the related stage. The requested mission report (in the directory specified in the ForceModelRpt Report Object) shows the data that came out of the mission run. If these data seem difficult to understand, you may try to change the output parameters in the Report commands to Keplerian orbital elements, or to some other method of tracking. You will notice slight variations in the data received from each report, due to the differences in governing forces in each Propagator.
